title: Hong Kong protesters inflamed by attack defy ban
text:
Hong Kong | Tens of thousands of protesters returned to the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday after an attack on a political activist and a lacklustre policy address by the city's leader inflamed tensions that show no signs of ending after five months.

Protesters, many wearing masks in defiance of a government ban, poured into Tsim Sha Tsui across the harbour from Hong Kong Island to march to the high-speed railway station linking the former British colony with mainland China.

Protesters smash glass panels at the Tsim Sha Tsui subway station. AP

Police earlier refused to approve the demonstration, initially called to protest the government's use of colonial-era emergency powers but instead focused on the attack on a prominent protest leader, Jimmy Sham. Police said he was attacked by four unidentified men with hammers and knives on Wednesday.

There were fears late on Sunday of another night of street violence in which protesters and police have attacked each other with tear gas and petrol bombs for consecutive weekends for months. Police on the scene raised a blue flag, warning demonstrators that the protest had not been authorised.

Thousands of protesters of all ages packed popular shopping streets around Tsim Sha Tsui. Most wore masks and some carried Catalan flags in a sign of solidarity for the protests taking place in Spain’s north-east.
description: Protesters, many wearing masks in defiance of a government ban, gathered in Tsim Tsa Tsui across the harbour from Hong Kong Island on Sunday.
